Fancy, bright and winged maid!</br>In thy night-drawn car convey'd,</br>O'er the green earth, and wide-spread main,</br>A thousand shadows in thy train,</br>A vary'd air-embody'd host,</br>To don what shapes thou pleasest most;</br>Brandish no more thy scorpion-stings</br>Around the destin'd couch of kings;</br>Nor in rebellion's ghastly size</br>A dire gigantic spectre rise:</br>Cease, for a while, in rooms of state</br>To damp the slumbers of the great;</br>In merit's lean-look'd form t' appear,</br>And hollow traitor in their ear:</br>Or freedom's holier garb bely,</br>While justice grinds her ax fast by:</br>Nor o'er the miser's eye-lids pour</br>The unrefreshing golden show'r;</br>Whilst, keen th' un-real bliss to feel,</br>His breast bedews the ruffian steel.

With these, (when next thou tak'st thy round)</br>The thoughts of guilty pride confound:</br>These swell the horrors and affright</br>Of conscience' keen-condemning night.</br>For this (nor, gracious pow'r!  repine)</br>A gentler ministry be thine:</br>Whate'er inspires the poet's theme,</br>Or lover's hope-enliven'd dream.</br>Monimia's mildest form assume;</br>Spread o'er thy cheeks her youthful bloom;</br>Unfold her eyes unblemish'd rays,</br>That melt to virtue as we gaze;</br>That envy's guiltiest wish disarm,</br>And view benign a kindred-charm;</br>Call all the graces from thy store,</br>Till thy creative pow'r be o'er;</br>Bid her each breathing sweet dispense,</br>And robe in her own innocence.

My wish is giv'n:  the spells begin;</br>Th' ideal world awakes within;</br>The lonely void of still repose</br>Pregnant with some new wonder grows;</br>See, by the twilight of the skies,</br>The beauteous apparition rise;</br>Slow, in Monimia's form, along</br>Glides to the harmony of song.

But who is he the virgin leads,</br>Whom high a flaming torch precedes,</br>In a gown of stainless lawn,</br>O'er each manly shoulder drawn?</br>Who, clad in robe of scarlet grain,</br>The boy that bears her flowing train?</br>Behind his back a quiver hung,</br>A bended bow across is flung;</br>His head and heels two wings unfold,</br>The azure feathers girt with gold.</br>Hymen!  'tis he who kind inspires</br>Joys unfeign'd and chaste desires.</br>And thou, of love deceitful child!</br>With tyger-heart, yet lamb-like mild,</br>Fantastic by thyself, and vain,</br>But seemly seen in Hymen's train;</br>If fate be to my wishes kind,</br>O!  may I find ye ever join'd;</br>But if the fates my wish deny,</br>My humble roof come ye not nigh.

The spell works on:  yet stop the day</br>While in the house of sleep I stay.</br>About me swells the sudden grove,</br>The wov'n arbourette of love;</br>Flow'rs spring unbidden o'er the ground,</br>And more than nature plants around.</br>Fancy, prolong the kind repose;</br>Still, still th' enchanting vision glows;</br>And now I gaze o'er all her charms,</br>Now sink transported in her arms.</br>Oh sacred energy divine!</br>All these enraptur'd scenes are thine.</br>Hail!  copious source of pure delight;</br>All hail!  thou heaven-revealed rite;</br>Endearing truth thy train attends,</br>And thou and meek-ey'd peace are friends:</br>Closer entwine the magic bow'r;</br>Thick rain the rose-empurpl'd show'r:</br>The mystic joy impatient flies</br>Th' unhallow'd gaze of vulgar eyes.</br>Unevy'd let the rich and great</br>Turmoil without, and parcel fate,</br>Indulging here, in bliss supreme,</br>Might I enjoy the golden dream:</br>But, ah!  the rapture must not stay;</br>For see!  she glides, she glides away.

Oh Fancy!  why did'st thou decoy</br>My thoughts into this dream of joy,</br>Then to forsake me all alone,</br>To mourn the fond delusion gone?</br>O!  back again, benign, restore</br>The pictur'd vision as before.</br>Yes, yes:  once more I fold my eyes;</br>Arise, ye dear deceits, arise.</br>Ideas bland!  where do ye rove?</br>Why fades my visionary grove?</br>Ye fickle troop of Morpheus' train,</br>Then will you, to the proud and vain,</br>From me, fantastic, wing your flight,</br>T' adorn the dream of false delight?</br>But now, seen in Monimia's air,</br>Can you assume a form less fair,</br>Some idle beauty's wish supply,</br>The mimic triumphs of her eye?</br>Grant all to me this live-long night,</br>Let charms detain the rising light;</br>For this one night my liv'ries wear,</br>And I absolve you for the year.

What time your poppy-crowned god</br>Sends his truth-telling scouts abroad,</br>Ere yet the cock to mattins rings,</br>And the lark, with mounting wings,</br>The simple village-swain has warn'd</br>To shake off sleep by labour earn'd;</br>Or on the rose's silken hem,</br>Aurora weeps her earliest gem;</br>Or, beneath the op'ning dawn,</br>Smiles the fair-extended lawn;</br>When in the soft-encircled shade</br>Ye find reclin'd the gentle maid,</br>Each busy motion laid to rest,</br>And all compos'd her peaceful breast:</br>Swift paint the fair internal scene,</br>The phantom-labours of your reign;</br>The living imag'ry adorn</br>With all the limnings of the morn,</br>With all the treasures nature keeps</br>Conceal'd below the foaming deeps;</br>Or dress'd in the rich waving pride,</br>That covers the green mountain's side,</br>Or blooms beneath the am'rous gale</br>In the wide-embosom'd vale.</br>Let pow'rful musick too essay</br>The magick of her hidden lay:</br>While each harsh thought away shall fly</br>Down the full stream of harmony,</br>Compassion mild shall fill their place,</br>Each gentle minister of grace,</br>Pity, that often melts to love</br>Let weeping pity, kind improve,</br>The soften'd heart, prepar'd to take</br>Whate'er impressions love shall make.</br>Oh!  in that kind, that secret hour,</br>When hate, when anger have no pow'r;</br>When sighing love, mild simple boy,</br>Courtship sweet, and tender joy,</br>Alone possess the fair-one's heart;</br>Let me then, Fancy, bear my part.

Oh goddess!  how I long t' appear;</br>The hour of dear success draws near:</br>See where the crouding shadows wait;</br>Haste and unfold the iv'ry gate:</br>Ye gracious forms, employ your aid,</br>Come in my anxious look array'd,</br>Come Love, come Hymen, at my pray'r,</br>Led by blyth hope, ye decent pair</br>By mutual confidence combin'd,</br>As erst in sleep I saw you join'd.</br>Fill my eyes with heart-swell'd tears,</br>Fill my breast with heart-born fears,</br>Half-utter'd, and only wish'd the rest;</br>Make sighs, and speaking sorrows prove,</br>Suffering much, how much I love;</br>Make the muses lyre complain,</br>Strung by me in warbled strain;</br>Let the melodious numbers flow</br>Pow'rful of a lover's woe,</br>Till, by the tender Orphian art,</br>I through her ear shall gain her heart.
Now, Fancy, now the fit is o'er;</br>I feel my sorrows vex no more:</br>But when condemn'd again to mourn,</br>Fancy, to my aid return.</br>
